subject: Re: [junit] initializing log4j via junit
msgSnippet: ... If a required jar isn t on the classpath, wouldn t there be an exception? ... I would go with the suspicion that it s a classpath thing. The classpath for
messageBody:
On 4/18/05, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
> My JUnit tests that use log4j work just fine from ant,
> so it must be a configuration issue. Are you using
> true log4j or Jakarta Commons Logging? Are you 100%
> sure log4j.jar is in your build.xml's classpath?
>
>
> Todd.
>

If a required jar isn't on the classpath, wouldn't there be an exception?

>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Brian Doyle [mailto:brianpdoyle@...]
> > Sent: Thursday, April 14, 2005 5:16 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] initializing log4j via junit
> >
> >
> >
> > Just wondering if someone where has been able to succesfully
> > initialize log4j within the junit task in an ant script.
> > There is a log4j.properties file in the same directory that
> > I'm running the junit task, the log4j.properties file is in
> > the classpath as well.
> > This works for me when running junit via IntelliJ so I know
> > that log4j.properties file is okay. I've even tried passing
> > in the jvm arg -Dlog4j.configuration parameter in the junit
> > task and that doesn't seem to work either. I must be doing
> > something obviously
> > wrong but I can't seem to figure it out. Thanks in advance.
> >
> >
> >
> > Brian Doyle
> >
> > I don't know about ignorance, and I don't care about apathy,
> > but I simply will not put up with intolerance! - Unknown
> >

I would go with the suspicion that it's a classpath thing. The
classpath for the junit task - have you used the verbose switch of ant
to check that it does contain the location of the log4j.properties
file?

James
